Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Allyza Rose Lustig  Allyza
Instructor: Allyza Rose Lustig  Allyza Lustig

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Allyza Rose Lustig  Allyza was great! Always really helpful and clear in posting instructions online, and kept groups on-task for their presentations.

Instructor: Allyza Rose Lustig  Allyza was organised and helpful in facilitating administrative tasks, but she rarely took part in discussions and I had very little interaction with her about my work. Given this is a graduate seminar, however, this is to be expected.

Instructor: Allyza Rose Lustig  Allyza wasn't particularly involved in class discussions, but her organizational skills were on point! Very quick and helpful in clarifying course expectations and deadlines.
Instructor: Allyza Rose Lustig  Allyza was helpful and very fast at responding to emails

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The class was incredible. I got so much out of it, however it did start to feel towards the end like we went off the rails. Students interjected in ways that were unhelpful. It started to feel a bit like a free-for-all and I thought that students overly critical comments were distracting in my learning. Overall- incredible course!!
Dr. Saxena is a great instructor who really engages and fosters questions and discussion

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The open-ended nature of the class was what made it so wonderful and also so frustrating.

This has been one of my favorite classes so far! The material was really interesting, and it's really exciting to be studying a field where everything is constantly being updated (as evidenced by the "news" portion of our class) and everything is relevant and used in contemporary policymaking. Alark was a wonderful professor, extremely responsive to students and always willing to meet and provide advice. Discussions were always lively, interesting, and even funny at times. Everyone was very engaged with the material (probably a product of the weekly reading responses).
The unique content. This is the first and only place I have been exposed to systems theory.
Alark created a very friendly and open atmosphere in the class for varied and interesting discussions.
Class discussion and weekly response. greatly elevated understanding on class materials.

Most helpful were discussions of resilience as a boundary term, of assessment frameworks for resilience, and of differing perspectives on the "right" way to do resilient work. Class discussion was also robust.
System thinking and interdisciplinary
The class discussions were extremely helpful and enlightening and great guest speakers

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: At times I wish that Alark had taken more control of the direction of discussion and kept us on a schedule.
It would be helpful if the instructor interfered more often when students were being overly critical.

More variation in the content. I feel the course became quite repetitive. I'd also value more perspectives on how resilience work can be applied to careers outside of academic research or working directly in the environmental sector.

Class discussion: the discussion is too open, allowing some student to throw an issue without limit. Some times discussion took substantial amount of time only on semantic issues just because some friends were really good on it.

I would like to focus more specifically on resilience/vulnerability assessments, and dive into one or two (including the Sustainable Livelihoods Framework) that Alark found most compelling. It would be useful to get practice using a framework, perhaps with a community in New Haven. This would be a great way to tie our coursework to practice, and perhaps to contribute to ongoing work in the community. Also, the student-led presentations were of varying quality and usefulness. Not sure how to remedy this. Also, if Alark is serious about capping the class at a reasonable number for discussion (12?18?) he should not then allow auditors to crowd the class. It is counterproductive to the point. The participation of the world fellows, however, was amazing. Finally, it could be fun to have an option of either the end of term paper OR of a client-driven project, allowing the course to again tie into real-world projects.

Far too much repetitive theory in the beginning. Case studies should be used from the start so that the students coming from all different backgrounds have points of reference to discuss. It felt often that everyone was just sort of talking to themselves, with specific examples in mind that other people didn't understand.
I think a case study class might be really interesting

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: fit with my future plan to working on developing countries issues.
This course helped further develop my interest/understanding of how to integrate public health and resilience

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I want to learn more about development work, and this helped a lot.
In preparation for a job next year engaged with climate change resilience work. I used this course to pivot from my background in history.
Want to improve my knowledge and skills on dealing with fundamental issues on developing countries.
As an MPH student I took the course because I was interested in learning about resilience theory and how resilience applied to health systems

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely! It was actually a little more theoretical than I originally expected, but that was not necessarily a bad thing, and probably necessary for a deep understanding of the material.
Yes, however learning to model would have been great or at least hearing how and where I can learn SD modelling at Yale.
yes
Meet my expectation.

Yes. This course is awesome. Alark is a great teacher and has a unique perspective from others at FES. I can't believe we don't have someone else who does modeling, or teaches vulnerability/resilience at FES.
Yes.
Learned a great deal about resilience theory and its application

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Quite honestly, my partner for the final paper was not very involved in either the presentation or the writing, so I do feel a little irritated that it will be recognized as a joint project when 90% of it was my work. Fortunately, work was much more balanced during the group presentation we gave in class, and that went smoothly.
I was very lucky that my partner was thorough and responsive!

learning from classmates with different perspectives and academic background was welcome. the opporutnity to collaborate on work is something that is rare in the history department and something I enjoyed doing!
The best part is it allows for sharing ideas and got different insight/perspective from other group member.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Find how the course is relevant to the work that you want to do and stay focused on that. It is interesting to hear from peers on why the class is important to them, but keep your goals in mind to make the course material meaningful to you. It's easy to lose that focus in a class like this.

Pick a good partner for the final paper it isn't an incredibly arduous assignment, but doing all the work when the project is supposed to be balanced is disappointing and frustrating. Do the reading every week! It is fascinating.
Take it!
be prepared to be bogged down in concepts, definitions, and frameworks -- there are a lot of them.
Take it! One of the best courses I've ever taken in Yale. The frameworks and ideas on building resilience are not only applicable to developing countries, but also for developed worlds.
Take the class because it is a very good class.
This class is great for students from different grad schools who are interested in resilience, climate change, sustainability, international development
